1 Journal of Molecular Catalysis, 68 (1991) 331-345 331 Particle size effect on the kinetics of p-chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation over platinum/alumina catalysts Bernard Coq*, Amina Tijani and Frangois Figueras Laboratoire de Chimie OrganiO Physique et CinetiO ChimiO Appliquees, URA 418 CNRS;; ENSCM, 8 rue de L Ecole Normale, 34053 Montpellier Cedex (France) (Received December 12, 1990; revised March 18, 1991) Abstract Hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene (CNB) has been studied, in methanol suspension at 303 K and atmospheric pressure, over a series of Pt/A1203 catalysts of varying dispersion (0.07 < H/Pt < 1.26). The kinetics obeys a modified Langmuir-Hinshelwood model with competitive adsorption between CNB and hydrogen. The adsorption competition no longer holds at high CNB concentration: on the Pt surface saturated by CNB, there are still Pt sites available for the chemisorption of the smaller hydrogen molecule. A rate law is then proposed which allows determination of both adsorption and rate constants. The specific rate constant (expressed on a per surface Pt atom basis as a turnover frequency) increases by one order of magnitude when the Pt dispersion decreases. This behaviour is interpreted in terms of a transition state bearing a weak negative charge more stabilized on the large Pt particles. This hypothesis agrees with the effect of substituents on the aromatic ring. The conversion of CNB leads to p-chloroanihne (CAN) as main product, p-chloronitrosobenzene and p-chlorophenylhydroxylamine as intermediates, with nitrobenzene, aniline and chlorobenzene as byproducts. The product selectivity depends on the Pt particle size. At high conversion, the highest selectivity in CAN (> 9896) is reached on large Pt particles. This can be interpreted by a lower relative adsorption strength between CAN and CNB on poorly dispersed catalysts; CAN is then easily removed from the surface by CNB, which prevents hydrodechlorination. Introduction Aromatic haloamines are of primary importance in industry for the production of many fine chemicals. The main route to these haloamines is through the reduction of the corresponding nitrocompounds, either with metal-acid systems or with hydrogen and a noble metal catalyst. Processes using the latter route are now growing, due to the environmental impact associated with the use of hydrochloric acid in the former route. However, a critical problem when reducing halonitroaromatics with noble metal is the control of selectivity. On the one hand, extensive dehalogenation to aromatic amines can occur. On the other hand byproducts, such as azoand azoxyhalobenzenes, can be formed. These drawbacks can be overcome *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/91/$3.50 0 1991- Elsevier Sequoia, Lausanne 332 by the addition of selectivity promoters such as bases or other electrondonating compounds [ 1-3 ]. Their interaction with the metal particles promotes the electronic properties of the catalyst [4]. However, the disadvantage of these methods is that they require extra processing steps to remove the adducts. The present trend is to modify the properties of noble metal catalysts without the use of complicated reaction procedures. This approach has been well examined in recent Congresses on Heterogeneous Catalysis and Fine Chemicals [5] for selective hydrogenation of many other functional groups. Modification of the catalytic properties of metal particles is usually related to the dispersion of the metallic phase, the nature of precursors and supports, and alloying with other metals. Therefore, the selectivity for the reduction of polyfunctional organic compounds depends on the different sensitivities of the reacting groups to the surface structure. In this respect, the gas phase hydrodechlorination of chlorobenzene appears to be sensitive to particle size and alloying effects on alumina-supported palladium catalysts [6, 7]. These effects, well known for many gas phase reactions, have been less investigated so far for reactions conducted in the liquid phase. Some of the few examples can be found in the patent literature, in which particle size effects have been suggested to be involved in the hydrogenation of halonitroaromatics over Pt catalysts [8, 9]. Likewise, Carturan et al. [10] reported that the rate of hydrogenation of nitro compounds decreases on increasing the dispersion of supported palladium. Therefore, the present work aimed to investigate the size effect of the platinum particles on the kinetics of p-chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation in the liquid phase. In order to isolate the particle size effect, alumina as support and platinum acetylacetonate as precursor were chosen to prepare Pt/A1203 catalysts of low metal/support interaction, as evidenced previously for rhodium-based catalysts [ 11 ]. Experimental Reactants Hydrogen of high purity grade (99.99go) was used for the catalytic experiments, and hydrogen of ultra-high purity (99.9995ss'o) for adsorption measurements. p-Chloronitrobenzene (Aldrich, purity > 99O), p-nitrophenol (Prolabo pur), p-nitroanisole (Aldrich, > 98%), p-fluoronitrobenzene (Fluka, > 98ss'o), nitrobenzene (Fluka, > 99.596) and methanol (SDS, > 99%) were used without further purification. Platinum acetylacetonate (Pt (acac)2, Strem Chemicals) was used as precursor for the catalysts. This precursor was chosen in order to avoid the effect of chlorine which could alter the chemisorption or catalytic properties [ 11 ]. The precursor was dissolved either in anhydrous toluene or in trichloroethylene (purities > 99.5ss'o). The carrier was y-alumina from Rhone-Poulenc (surface area 200 m2 g-1). Preparation of platinum catalysts The Pt/A1203 samples were prepared by adsorption of Pt(acac)2 on yalumina. The requisite amount of Pt(acac)2 was dissolved in toluene or 333 trichloroethylene, then contacted with y -A1203 at room temperature for several hours. Afterward, the solution was either evaporated or filtered. These solids were dried at 298 K under vacuum. Some catalysts were then subjected to a calcination step under air at 673 K for 4 h. Finally, all the samples were reduced under varying conditions. The details of catalyst preparations are given in Table 1. Characterization The chemisorption of hydrogen was carried out in a conventional volumetric apparatus, at 298 K in the 0-20 kPa pressure range. The sample was first reactivated in situ under flowing hydrogen at 573 K overnight, then evacuated to 1 X 2 10-' Pa, at the same temperature, for 3 h. Hydrogen was then adsorbed. The linear portion of the isotherm, usually between 10 and 20 kPa, was extrapolated to zero pressure to determine the hydrogen uptake. On highly dispersed samples, with particle sizes below 1 run, the stoichiometry of hydrogen adsorption reached values higher than unity. It was reported recently that the stoichiometry of hydrogen adsorption changes with metal particle size and can surpass unity on small particles [ 12 ]. This introduces an uncertainty as to the number of surface Pt atoms, which can reach 209'0 on well-dispersed samples. The size of the metallic particles was checked by transmission electron microscopy using a JEOL 100CX apparatus. The agreement with chemisorption is generally good. The chemical compositions of the solids were determined after dissolution by elemental analysis at the Service Central d'Analyse (CNRS, Solaize, France). The main characteristics of the catalysts are included in Table 1. Catalytic tests Hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene (CNB) was carried out in a 50 ml four-necked flask connected to a cooler, a dropping funnel, a hydrogen gas line and a pipe used to sample the reaction mixture. The catalyst was reactivated in situ under flowing hydrogen at 523 K overnight. After cooling to the reaction temperature (T,.=303 K unless otherwise specified), 25 ml of the reactant solution (CNB in methanol) was introduced through one arm of the flask. This solution was previously purged with bubbling hydrogen. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 700 rpm, and the reaction was carried out at atmospheric pressure under HZ flow. Chemical analysis of the products was performed by gas chromatography (Carlo Erba, model 2450), equipped with a FID detector and a capillary column J & W (30 m X 0.32 mm i.d., DB1 apolar phase). Reactants and products were identified with authentic samples, and GC/MS coupling. Discussion As mentioned above, the initial rate goes through a maximum value as a function of CNB concentration, in the range of concentration and pressure of reactants used here. This behaviour reflects the competitive adsorption between hydrogen and CNB for the same Pt sites. However, the rate does not fall to zero at high CNB concentrations, as expected for a classical Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic model with competitive adsorption of the reactants. Actually, the rate tends to an asymptotic value. In order to rationalize this peculiar behaviour, we propose a modified Langmuir-_Hinshelwood kinetic model based on the following assumptions: (1) competitive adsorption between H2 and CNB occurs at low or medium concentrations. (2) at high CNB concentrations, the Pt surface is saturated with respect to CNB adsorption, but due to dipolar interactions or steric hindrance, the substrate cannot cover all the Pt surface and there are still enough Pt sites 340 available for the chemisorption of the much smaller hydrogen molecule. This model has some aspects common with that proposed by Kut et al. (181 for the hydrogenation of 2,4-dimethylnitrobenzene over a Pd/C catalyst. However, the noncompetitive adsorption of organic species and hydrogen assumed by these authors does not fit our experimental data. A rigourous treatment is not obvious, therefore we propose several approximations: (1) at low CNB conversion (initial conditions) the Pt surface is totally covered by CNB and/or H2, i.e. OR + OH =1. (2) due to repulsive dipole/dipole interaction, or to steric hindrance, one molecule of adsorbed CNB inhibits a surface area S with respect to another CNB adsorption, but a lower surface s for hydrogen adsorption (Scheme 2). The ratio s/S is termed ss (0 < ss < 1). Let us assume that the .1R/.1H ratio remains constant between Pt(VI) and Pt(M samples; the rate cosntant k for Pt(IV) can then be estimated as 1.7 10-' mol g`' s-' (K=17 s-'). Actually, this value is probably slightly underestimated, because the .1R/.1H ratio is lower on Pt(IV) than on Pt(VI) samples, the Cm,, value being shifted to higher CN13 concentration. It appears however that the change of the intrinsic rate constant K as a function of Pt dispersion probably does not exceed one order of magnitude. This effect of particle size compares reasonably well with that reported by Carturan et al. [10] for Pd catalysts: a thirtyfold increase of turnover number when Pd dispersion decreases. This last behaviour can have two interpretations, based on either an electronic or a geometric effect: (1) When the size of metal particles decreases, the Local Density of State (LDS) at the Fermi level also decreases [25]. Several authors consider small particles as `electron-deficient' species with respect to the larger ones [26, 27]. In another respect, the value of the intrinsic rate constant K of the surface reaction increases slightly with particle size, i.e. with the LDS at the Fermi level. Therefore, a negatively charged transition state would be favoured on large Pt particles. Such a surface species could be formed by the attack on the N-O bond by a weak nucleophilic agent, such as chemisorbed hydrogen, as previously suggested by Galvagno et al. [16]. However, the extent of negative charge is probably low, and seems more or less independent of the substituent on the aromatic ring, as evidenced by the poor correlation between the rate constant and the Hammett substituent coefficient o,P (Fig. 5). A similar conclusion was reached by Aramendia et al. [28], who proposed a radical mechanism for the hydrogenation of substituted nitroaromatics over Pt/Si02 AIP04. (2) During hydrogenation of the -NOZ group, N-O bond fission occurs. Accommodation of the fragments with the surface could require several Pt atoms and multiply bonded species. With both carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons, smaller particles are less able to form such multiply-bonded species than are larger ones [29[. This geometric effect could also explain the decrease in the K value when Pt dispersion increases. 343 Let us compare now the product selectivities of the CNB hydrogenation at high conversion (= 60%) on the various samples (Table 3). For Pt/A1203 catalysts with particle sizes lower than 30 A, the hydrodechlorination of CAN to AN becomes significant (> 3%), whereas it remains low on large Pt particles (Pt(IV) sample). This behaviour can be explained in two ways: (1) The relative strength of adsorption between CNB and CAN increases when Pt dispersion decreases. Hence, p-chloroaniline is easily desorbed from the Pt surface and dechlorination is suppressed. (2) Large Pt particles exhibit a lower activity for C -Cl bond hydrogenolysis than do smaller ones. No study on the reactivity of the C-Cl bond in aromatic series as a function of Pt particle size has previously been reported. However, the cleavage of this bond was found faster on large Pd and Rh particles supported on alumina [6]. We can then reasonably assume that a similar behaviour occurs with Pt/AI203 catalysts. The first of the above propositions is thus more probable, and agrees with the lower inhibiting effect of CAN on the initial reaction rate of CNB hydrogenation over Pt(IV) compared to Pt(II) samples (Table 4); hence, the relative adsorption strength between CNB and CAN is larger on Pt(IV) than on Pt(II) catalysts. However, the competition of adsorption between CNB and HZ disappears at high CNB concentration. In that case a close-packed coverage of CNB forms, but Pt sites still remain free for adsorption of the much smaller hydrogen molecule. The TON decreases by one order of magnitude when the dispersion of Pt decreases, due either to a higher interaction with the electron-deficient small metal particles, or to the requirement of multiplybonded species unfavoured on small particles. The lower strength of adsorption of CAN compared to CNB on large Pt particles favours the selective hydrogenation of CNB to CAN. X244 9180091G 0304-5102(91)80091-G 10.1016/0304-5102(91)80091-G Particle size effect on the kinetics of p-chloronitrobenzene hydrogenation over platinum/alumina catalysts Bernard Coq ∗ Amina Tijani François Figuéras Laboratoire de Chimie Organique Physique et Cinétique Chimique Appliquées, URA 418 CNRS; ENSCM, 8 rue de l'Ecole Normale, 34053 Montpellier Cedex France * Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. Hydrogenation of p-chloronitrobenzene (CNB) has been studied, in methanol suspension at 303 K and atmospheric pressure, over a series of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts of varying dispersion (0.07 < H/Pt < 1.26). The kinetics obeys a modified Langmuir—Hinshelwood model with competitive adsorption between CNB and hydrogen. The adsorption competition no longer holds at high CNB concentration: on the Pt surface saturated by CNB, there are still Pt sites available for the chemisorption of the smaller hydrogen molecule. A rate law is then proposed which allows determination of both adsorption and rate constants. The specific rate constant (expressed on a per surface Pt atom basis as a turnover frequency) increases by one order of magnitude when the Pt dispersion decreases. This behaviour is interpreted in terms of a transition state bearing a weak negative charge more stabilized on the large Pt particles. This hypothesis agrees with the effect of substituents on the aromatic ring. The conversion of CNB leads to p-chloroaniline (CAN) as main product, p-chloronitrosobenzene and p-chlorophenylhydroxylamine as intermediates, with nitrobenzene, aniline and chlorobenzene as byproducts. The product selectivity depends on the Pt particle size. At high conversion, the highest selectivity in CAN (>98%) is reached on large Pt particles. This can be interpreted by a lower relative adsorption strength between CAN and CNB on poorly dispersed catalysts; CAN is then easily removed from the surface by CNB, which prevents hydrodechlorination.
